       Introduced  by  Sen.  ROBACH -- read twice and ordered printed, and when
         printed to be committed to the Committee on Education

       AN ACT to amend the education law, in relation  to  instruction  on  the
         history of people with disabilities

         THE  PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK, REPRESENTED IN SENATE AND ASSEM-
       BLY, DO ENACT AS FOLLOWS:

    1    Section 1. Subdivisions 1 and 3 of section 801 of the  education  law,
    2  as  amended  by  chapter 574 of the laws of 1997, are amended to read as
    3  follows:
    4    1. In order to promote a spirit of patriotic  and  civic  service  and
    5  obligation  and  to foster in the children of the state moral and intel-
    6  lectual qualities which are essential in preparing  to  meet  the  obli-
    7  gations of citizenship in peace or in war, the regents of The University
    8  of  the  State  of  New  York  shall prescribe courses of instruction in
    9  patriotism, citizenship, and human rights issues, with particular atten-
   10  tion to the study of the inhumanity of genocide, slavery (including  the
   11  freedom  trail  and  underground  railroad), the Holocaust, and the mass
   12  starvation in Ireland from 1845 to 1850, AND THE HISTORY OF PEOPLE  WITH
   13  DISABILITIES,  TO  BE  CONCENTRATED DURING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO THE THIRD
   14  FULL WEEK OF OCTOBER, to be maintained and followed in all  the  schools
   15  of the state. The boards of education and trustees of the several cities
   16  and  school districts of the state shall require instruction to be given
   17  in such courses, by the teachers employed in the  schools  therein.  All
   18  pupils attending such schools, over the age of eight years, shall attend
   19  upon such instruction.
   20    Similar  courses  of instruction shall be prescribed and maintained in
   21  private schools in the state, and all pupils in such schools over  eight
   22  years  of age shall attend upon such courses. If such courses are not so
   23  established and maintained in a private school, attendance upon instruc-
   24  tion in such school shall not  be  deemed  substantially  equivalent  to

        EXPLANATION--Matter in ITALICS (underscored) is new; matter in brackets
                             [ ] is old law to be omitted.
                                                                  LBD01984-01-1

       S. 560                              2

    1  instruction  given  to  pupils  of like age in the public schools of the
    2  city or district in which such pupils reside.
    3    3.  The  regents  shall  determine the subjects to be included in such
    4  courses of instruction in  patriotism,  citizenship,  and  human  rights
    5  issues,  with  particular  attention  to  the study of the inhumanity of
    6  genocide, slavery (including the freedom  trail  and  underground  rail-
    7  road),  the  Holocaust,  and the mass starvation in Ireland from 1845 to
    8  1850, THE HISTORY  OF  PEOPLE  WITH  DISABILITIES,  TO  BE  CONCENTRATED
    9  DURING,  BUT  NOT  LIMITED TO THE THIRD FULL WEEK OF OCTOBER, and in the
   10  history, meaning, significance and  effect  of  the  provisions  of  the
   11  constitution  of the United States, the amendments thereto, the declara-
   12  tion of independence, the constitution of the state of New York and  the
   13  amendments  thereto, and the period of instruction in each of the grades
   14  in such subjects. They shall adopt rules providing for  attendance  upon
   15  such instruction and for such other matters as are required for carrying
   16  into  effect  the objects and purposes of this section. The commissioner
   17  shall be responsible for the enforcement of such section and shall cause
   18  to be inspected and supervise  the  instruction  to  be  given  in  such
   19  subjects. The commissioner may, in his OR HER discretion, cause all or a
   20  portion  of  the  public school money to be apportioned to a district or
   21  city to be withheld for  failure  of  the  school  authorities  of  such
   22  district  or  city  to provide instruction in such courses and to compel
   23  attendance upon such instruction, as herein prescribed, and for  a  non-
   24  compliance with the rules of the regents adopted as [herein] provided IN
   25  THIS SECTION.
   26    S 2. This act shall take effect immediately.
